texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 🔨  WORK IN PROGRESS!  I'm still finding some additional issues and I'll write those up here as soon as I find some solutions.
texts.text: 🔨  WORK IN PROGRESS!  I'm still finding some additional issues and I'll write those up here as soon as I find some solutions.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: With my 4th Gen X1 Carbon beginning to age (especially the battery), it was time for an upgrade. I now have a T490 with a 10th gen Intel CPU and a discrete NVIDIA MX250 GPU. This laptop spec was just released on Black Friday!
texts.text: With my 4th Gen X1 Carbon beginning to age (especially the battery), it was time for an upgrade. I now have a T490 with a 10th gen Intel CPU and a discrete NVIDIA MX250 GPU. This laptop spec was just released on Black Friday!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As with any new technology, there are bound to be some quirks in Linux that require some workarounds. This laptop is no exception!
texts.text: As with any new technology, there are bound to be some quirks in Linux that require some workarounds. This laptop is no exception!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This post will grow over time as I find more workarounds and fixes for this laptop.
texts.text: This post will grow over time as I find more workarounds and fixes for this laptop.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Installing Fedora
texts.text: Installing Fedora

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start by downloading whichever installation method of Fedora you prefer. Since this laptop is fairly new, I went with the network installation (included in the Server ISOs) and chose to apply updates during installation.
texts.text: Start by downloading whichever installation method of Fedora you prefer. Since this laptop is fairly new, I went with the network installation (included in the Server ISOs) and chose to apply updates during installation.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On the first boot, wait for the LUKS screen to appear and ask for your password to decrypt the drive. Hit
texts.text: On the first boot, wait for the LUKS screen to appear and ask for your password to decrypt the drive. Hit

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CTRL-ALT-DEL
texts.text: CTRL-ALT-DEL

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: at the password prompt and wait for the grub screen to appear on reboot.
texts.text: at the password prompt and wait for the grub screen to appear on reboot.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Why are we issuing the three finger salute?  If you allow the laptop to fully boot, it will hang when it starts gdm. There are some nouveau issues in the system journal that provide hints but I haven't made sense of them yet. By preventing the system from fully booting, the grub success flag won't be set and you will see the grub menu at the next boot that is normally hidden from you.
texts.text: Why are we issuing the three finger salute?  If you allow the laptop to fully boot, it will hang when it starts gdm. There are some nouveau issues in the system journal that provide hints but I haven't made sense of them yet. By preventing the system from fully booting, the grub success flag won't be set and you will see the grub menu at the next boot that is normally hidden from you.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Press
texts.text: Press

texts.label: code
texts.orig: e
texts.text: e

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: on the first line of the grub menu. Find the longest line (it usually has
texts.text: on the first line of the grub menu. Find the longest line (it usually has

texts.label: code
texts.orig: rhgb quiet
texts.text: rhgb quiet

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ) and add this text to the end:
texts.text: ) and add this text to the end:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: rd.driver.blacklist=nouveau
texts.text: rd.driver.blacklist=nouveau

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Press
texts.text: Press

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CTRL-X
texts.text: CTRL-X

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to boot the system. Enter your LUKS password when asked and you should boot straight into gdm!
texts.text: to boot the system. Enter your LUKS password when asked and you should boot straight into gdm!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You have two options here:
texts.text: You have two options here:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Blacklist nouveau until bugs are fixed.'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Blacklist nouveau until bugs are fixed.'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children="Install NVIDIA's proprietary drivers.">]
texts.text: [<RawText children="Install NVIDIA's proprietary drivers.">]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm going to install NVIDIA's proprietary drivers that have power management and optimus support built in already. All of these steps here come from  RPM Fusion's excellent NVIDIA documentation .
texts.text: I'm going to install NVIDIA's proprietary drivers that have power management and optimus support built in already. All of these steps here come from  RPM Fusion's excellent NVIDIA documentation .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start by installing RPMFusion's repository configuration:
texts.text: Start by installing RPMFusion's repository configuration:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sudo dnf install https://download1.rpmfusion.org/free/fedora/rpmfusion-free-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm https://download1.rpmfusion.org/nonfree/fedora/rpmfusion-nonfree-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm
texts.text: sudo dnf install https://download1.rpmfusion.org/free/fedora/rpmfusion-free-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm https://download1.rpmfusion.org/nonfree/fedora/rpmfusion-nonfree-release-$(rpm -E %fedora).noarch.rpm

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Next, install the proprietary drivers.
texts.text: Next, install the proprietary drivers.

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sudo dnf install akmod-nvidia
texts.text: sudo dnf install akmod-nvidia

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When the packages are installed, run
texts.text: When the packages are installed, run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: akmods
texts.text: akmods

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to build the
texts.text: to build the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: nvidia
texts.text: nvidia

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: kernel module (this took about a minute on my laptop):
texts.text: kernel module (this took about a minute on my laptop):

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# sudo akmods
Checking kmods exist for 5.3.15-300.fc31.x86_64            [  OK  ]
texts.text:
# sudo akmods
Checking kmods exist for 5.3.15-300.fc31.x86_64            [  OK  ]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Reboot your laptop. If all goes well, your laptop should boot right up without interaction (except for entering your LUKS password).
texts.text: Reboot your laptop. If all goes well, your laptop should boot right up without interaction (except for entering your LUKS password).

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: NVIDIA power management
texts.text: NVIDIA power management

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can enable some power management features for the NVIDIA GPU by following the (somewhat lengthy) documentation about  PCI-Express Runtime D3 (RTD3) Power Management . I've enabled the most aggressive setting by adding the following to
texts.text: You can enable some power management features for the NVIDIA GPU by following the (somewhat lengthy) documentation about  PCI-Express Runtime D3 (RTD3) Power Management . I've enabled the most aggressive setting by adding the following to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/modprobe.d/nvidia.conf
texts.text: /etc/modprobe.d/nvidia.conf

texts.label: code
texts.orig: options nvidia "NVreg_DynamicPowerManagement=0x02"
texts.text: options nvidia "NVreg_DynamicPowerManagement=0x02"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Reboot your laptop for the change to take effect.
texts.text: Reboot your laptop for the change to take effect.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: BIOS Updates
texts.text: BIOS Updates

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My laptop was shipped to me with the 1.04 BIOS, but 1.06 is the latest (as of this writing). Follow these steps to update:
texts.text: My laptop was shipped to me with the 1.04 BIOS, but 1.06 is the latest (as of this writing). Follow these steps to update:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Open the
texts.text: Open the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go to the
texts.text: Go to the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Look for a firmware update (usually at the end of the list)
texts.text: Look for a firmware update (usually at the end of the list)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click update and wait for a notification
texts.text: Click update and wait for a notification

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Reboot
texts.text: Reboot

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The firmware capsule is found on the first reboot and then the laptop reboots to install the new firmware. You'll see some screens about backing up the BIOS and some self-health related things. They take a while to complete, but my laptop came right up on 1.06 without any problems!
texts.text: The firmware capsule is found on the first reboot and then the laptop reboots to install the new firmware. You'll see some screens about backing up the BIOS and some self-health related things. They take a while to complete, but my laptop came right up on 1.06 without any problems!
